title: Lewis Hamilton blames Mercedes after Japanese Grand Prix failure in X-rated rant
text:

Lewis Hamilton accused Mercedes of a "f*** up" that denied him victory in Japan - before joining his team to toast their sixth straight world championship double.

The Brit was livid that a questionable strategy decision - one which he blasted on the radio - saw him finish third as team-mate Valtteri Bottas stormed to a surprise triumph at the Japanese GP.

His anger was short lived though as he joined his team to celebrate their remarkable sixth constructors' world title and even belted out a rendition of Queen's 'We Are The Champions'.

And Hamilton will wrap up a sixth world title of his own if he wins in Mexico a week next Sunday and Bottas, whose previously victory came back in April, finishes fifth or lower.

(Image: XPB Images/Press Association Images)

(Image: FRANCK ROBICHON/EPA-EFE/REX)

But it could have been another story had Mercedes not made an uncharacteristic mistake with their strategy that ultimately cost Hamilton a crucial 10 seconds... and more.

They opted to keep him out for three laps longer than Bottas and then put him on the wrong tyres which ultimately forced the Brit to make a second unscheduled stop.

"That was just a f***-up," said Hamilton complaining to his race engineer, Pete Bonnington. "How have I lost that much time? I am basically out of the race."

(Image: KIM HONG-JI/POOL/EPA-EFE/REX)

(Image: REUTERS)

Hamilton is now 64 points clear of Bottas with four rounds and 104 points left to play for and on the brink of moving to within one title of Michael Schumacher's record of seven.

Despite Mercedes wrapping up a sixth successive constructors' championship yesterday - an unprecedented achievement - a dejected Hamilton admitted he's unlikely to wrap up the title for a third successive year in Mexico City.

He said: "I don't anticipate it will be Mexico where I win the championship. We still have a battle.

"We could have been done better. There have been multiple scenarios this year where that has been the case. We should have got a one-two but the strategy was not optimum for me.

(Image: REUTERS)

"I came out from the pits and realised I lost 10 seconds, and I am like, why? If they told me I would have been that far behind Valtteri I would have said no to them, and stopped earlier."

For Bottas, it was a morale-boosting victory after a dreadful run of form that has seen his team-mate spearhead all-conquering Mercedes' challenge for another title crown.

Mercedes' success yesterday, combined with Ferrari’s failure to improve on their second and seventh place with Vettel and Charles Leclerc respectively, means a Silver Arrow driver is guaranteed to win the drivers’ title this season.

It breaks the record of five title doubles set by Michael Schumacher and Ferrari from 2000-4 and confirms this dominant Mercedes team as the greatest in Formula One history.

Bottas said: "I'm happy, very happy. Obviously it was a close qualifying and starting third is not easy here but you don't give up and anything is possible."

Indeed, Bottas seemingly had the win wrapped up at the first corner following Vettel’s alleged false start, for which he was found not guilty, and Leclerc’s similarly poor start off the line.

"I had a really nice start and Sebastian had an issue so I got the lead and the pace was super good. I enjoyed it and had fun," Bottas added.

Leclerc’s misery was compounded following an early collision with Red Bull’s Max Verstappen and he dropped one place down to seventh after stewards handed him a post-race, 15-second penalty for a series of offences.

Another day to savour for Mercedes, another one to forget for Ferrari.
description: Lewis Hamilton finished third at Suzuka behind Mercedes teammate Valtteri Bottas and Sebastian Vettel but remains in course for sixth world title
